description: From Middle English ransaken, from Old Norse rannsaka, from rann (“house”) + saka (“search”); probably influenced by sack. Compare Danish ransage, Swedish rannsaka.

examples: Perhaps this stone also will turn up in the ransack of the sultan's treasury.

verbs.description: ransack (third-person singular simple present ransacks, present participle ransacking, simple past and past participle ransacked)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To loot or pillage. See also sack.
(transitive) To make a vigorous and thorough search of (a place, person) with a view to stealing something, especially when leaving behind a state of disarray.
examples: to ransack a house for valuables

entries.meaning: To violate; to ravish; to deflower.
